metadata.case_name: Petitioners (Landowners) v. State of Himachal Pradesh

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954) passed by Legislative Assembly of old State of Himachal Pradesh.
President of India gave assent to the Bill on November 23, 1954, making it the Abolition Act.
Abolition Act brought into force on January 26, 1955 by notification under s.1(3).
Section 11 confers right on tenants (not sub-tenants) to acquire landowner's interest on payment of compensation.
Section 14 permits tenant to acquire portion of lands on surrender of rest.
Section 15 allows State Government to acquire landowner's rights by notification, vesting in State free from encumbrances.
Section 16 provides compensation to landowners under ss.12 and 13.
Section 27 deems rights of landowners with land revenue > Rs.125/year transferred to State; compensation per Schedule II or I.
Schedule II compensation may be no more than twice land revenue.
Section 39 fixes maximum rent at one fourth of crop, possibly covering land revenue, rates, cesses.
Old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur were separate Part C States under First Schedule to Constitution.
Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951) applied to old Himachal Pradesh; Bilaspur excluded.
Old Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly had 36 seats per Third Schedule; elections held in 1952.
Members took oath under s.14 Part C States Act; elected Shri Jaiwant Ram as Speaker.
Bill (Himachal 15 of 1953) introduced in first session of old Himachal Pradesh Assembly in 1953.
Parliament enacted Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act, 1954 (32 of 1954); assented May 28, 1954; into force July 1, 1954.
New State Act s.3 creates new Part C State 'Himachal Pradesh' uniting old HP and Bilaspur.
New State Act s.12: Legislative Assembly for new State with 41 seats by direct election.
New State Act s.15(1): Sitting members of old HP Assembly deemed elected to new Assembly for same constituencies.
President amended Delimitation Order for Bilaspur constituencies under s.14(2).
Notification dated July 7, 1954 summoned 'Second Session, 1954' of Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly from August 16, 1954.
No notification under s.74 Representation of the People Act, 1951 constituting new Assembly.
36 old members did not take fresh oath or affirmation as members of new Assembly.
No election of Speaker for new Assembly; old Speaker Jaiwant Ram granted leave.
Elections held May 13, 1955 for 5 Bilaspur seats, bringing total to 41.
Petitioners are landowners whose properties affected by Abolition Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Abolition Act is void for not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature of the new State of Himachal Pradesh.
Whether provisions of Chapter III and Chapter VIII of the Abolition Act are repugnant to the Constitution (Arts. 14, 19, 31).

petitioner_arguments.text: Abolition Act entirely void as not passed by duly constituted legislature.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act, 1954; Government of Part C States Act, 1951; Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.74

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Ch. III and Ch. VIII repugnant to Constitution.

respondent_arguments.text: s.15(1) New State Act deems 36 old members elected to new Assembly; 5 vacancies from Bilaspur do not vitiate under s.35 Part C States Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: New State Act s.15, s.16; Part C States Act s.35; Representation of the People Act s.147(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Absence of fresh oath is mere irregularity cured by s.35 Part C States Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Part C States Act s.14, s.35; Articles 100(2), 189(2) Constitution

court_reasoning.text: New State Act created new Himachal Pradesh; old HP and Bilaspur ceased to exist; new Assembly of 41 members required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.15(1) only deems old members elected but does not constitute the Assembly without s.74 ROP Act notification.

court_reasoning.text: Notification of July 7, 1954 summoned 'second session' of old Assembly, not first session of new; no fresh oath, no Speaker election.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lieutenant Governor summoned old Assembly; Bill lapsed on dissolution.

court_reasoning.text: s.35 Part C States Act cures irregularities in existing Assembly, not absence of constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No duly constituted new Assembly existed to pass the Act.

holdings.text: Abolition Act void as not passed by duly constituted Legislative Assembly of new Himachal Pradesh.

statutes_cited.name: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as unconstitutional; provisions for tenant acquisition, State vesting, compensation, rent fixation

statutes_cited.name: Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act, 1954 (32 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Created new Himachal Pradesh; deemed old members elected but did not constitute new Assembly

statutes_cited.name: Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governed old HP Assembly; s.35 on vacancies/irregularities does not apply to non-constitution

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification under s.74 required to constitute Assembly

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights enforcement; comparison for oaths, irregularities

outcome.summary: Abolition Act held void for not being passed by duly constituted legislature of new Himachal Pradesh; interference with petitioners' property rights unjustified; no need to decide second issue.
outcome.relief_granted: Petitions under Art.32 allowed; Act declared invalid

key_quotes.text: the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 15(1) of the New State Act only provides that each of the 36 sitting members... shall be deemed to have been elected... does not say that these 36 persons alone constitute the Legislative Assembly
key_quotes.speaker: court
